discovery_rule.name: Instances
discovery_rule.params:
<parms type="oracle" prefix="oracle."> <server> <discovery time="120" item="discovery.DBforBIX.config[instanceid,{$DSN}]" names="INST_ID">SELECT inst_id FROM gv$instance</discovery> <query time="60" item="stats[%1,%2]"> SELECT inst_id, REPLACE(name,' ','_'), value FROM gv$sysstat WHERE name IN ('user I/O wait time','physical read total bytes','physical write total bytes','lob reads','lob writes','db block changes','db block gets','consistent gets','physical reads','physical reads direct','physical writes direct','redo writes','physical read requests optimized','physical write requests optimized') </query> <query time="60" item="stats[%1,%2]"> select inst_id,'dbhitratio',trunc((sum(decode(name,'consistent gets', value,0)) + sum(decode(name,'db block gets', value,0)) - sum(decode(name,'physical reads', value,0))) / (sum(decode(name,'consistent gets', value,0)) + sum(decode(name,'db block gets', value,0)) ) * 100,2) "hit_ratio" FROM gv$sysstat group by inst_id </query>
<query time="900" item="parameter[%1,%2]">SELECT inst_id,name,value FROM gv$parameter WHERE name IN ('processes','sessions','sga_max_size','memory_target','memory_max_target','shared_pool_reserved_size','db_block_size','log_buffer','db_files','parallel_server_instances','cluster_database_instances','db_flashback_retention_target','distributed_lock_timeout','create_bitmap_area_size','bitmap_merge_area_size','hash_area_size','sort_area_size','pga_aggregate_target','pga_aggregate_limit')</query>
<query time="60" item="sgastat[%1,%2]"> SELECT inst_id,decode(nvl(pool,'none'), 'shared pool','pool_sql_area', 'none','sga_bufcache', 'java pool','java_pool', 'large pool','large_pool' ), SUM(bytes) bytes FROM GV$SGASTAT where (nvl(pool,'none'),name) in ( ('shared pool','sql area'), ('shared pool','SQLA'), ('none','db_block_buffers'), ('none','buffer_cache') ) or pool in ('java pool','large pool') group by inst_id, nvl(pool,'none') </query> <query time="60" item="sgastat[%1,%2]"> SELECT inst_id, name, sum(bytes) bytes FROM GV$SGASTAT where pool is null and name in ('fixed_sga','log_buffer') group by inst_id, name </query> <query time="60" item="sgastat[%1,%2]"> SELECT inst_id, 'pool_misc',sum(bytes) bytes FROM GV$SGASTAT where pool in ('shared pool') and name not in ('library cache','dictionary cache','free memory','sql area','SQLA') group by inst_id </query> <query time="60" item="sgastat[%1,%2]"> SELECT inst_id, REPLACE(name,' ','_'),sum(bytes) bytes FROM GV$SGASTAT where pool in ('shared pool') and name in ('dictionary cache','free memory','library cache','sql area','SQLA') group by inst_id, name </query>
<query time="60" item="uptime[%1]" nodata="0">SELECT inst_id, ROUND((sysdate-startup_time)*86400) retvalue FROM gv$instance</query> <query time="60" item="procnum[%1]">SELECT inst_id,COUNT(*) procnum from gv$process group by inst_id</query> <query time="120" item="miss_latch[%1]">SELECT inst_id,SUM(misses) FROM GV$LATCH group by inst_id</query> <query time="120" item="sessions[%1]" nodata="0">SELECT inst_id, COUNT(*) FROM gv$session group by inst_id</query> <query time="120" item="session_system[%1]" nodata="0">SELECT inst_id, COUNT(*) FROM gv$session WHERE type='BACKGROUND' group by inst_id</query> <query time="120" item="session_active[%1]" nodata="0">SELECT inst_id, COUNT(*) FROM gv$session WHERE type!='BACKGROUND' AND status='ACTIVE' group by inst_id</query> <query time="120" item="users_connected[%1]" nodata="0"> SELECT inst_id, count(username) FROM gv$session WHERE username is not null group by inst_id </query> <query time="600" item="dbfilesize">SELECT SUM(NVL(bytes,0)) val FROM dba_data_files</query> <query time="600" item="dbsize"> SELECT SUM(NVL(a.bytes, 0) - NVL(f.bytes, 0)) val FROM sys.dba_tablespaces d, (SELECT tablespace_name, SUM(bytes) bytes FROM dba_data_files GROUP BY tablespace_name) a, (SELECT tablespace_name, SUM(bytes) bytes FROM dba_free_space GROUP BY tablespace_name) f WHERE d.tablespace_name = a.tablespace_name(+) AND d.tablespace_name = f.tablespace_name(+) AND NOT ( d.extent_management LIKE 'LOCAL' AND d.contents LIKE 'TEMPORARY' ) </query> <query time="600" item="session_io_log" nodata="none"> select LISTAGG(SUBSTR(sessions_tab,1,395),chr(10)) WITHIN GROUP(ORDER BY PCT desc) sessions from ( select INST_ID||': '||'PCT[R/W/T,MB/s]='||PCT||'['||SESSION_IO_R_MBps||'/'||SESSION_IO_W_MBps||'/'||TOTAL_IO_MBps||'];SQL_(ID/FULL_PLAN_HV)='||SQL_ID||'/'||sql_full_plan_hash_value||';SID='||sid||'#'||SERIAL#||';(SCH/USER)NAME='||SCHEMANAME||'/'||USERNAME||';STATUS='||STATUS||';TYPE='||TYPE||';OSUSER='||OSUSER||';PROGRAM='||REGEXP_REPLACE(PROGRAM,'@.*$','')||'@'||MACHINE||';PROCESS='||PROCESS||';'||DESCRIPTION sessions_tab, PCT from ( select b.inst_id,b.sid,b.SERIAL#,b.SCHEMANAME,b.OSUSER,b.USERNAME,b.STATUS,b.SQL_ID,b.PROCESS,b.PROGRAM,b.MACHINE,b.TYPE, round(100*(sio.SESSION_IO_R+sio.SESSION_IO_W)/fio.TOTAL_IO,2) PCT,round(sio.SESSION_IO_R,2) SESSION_IO_R_MBps, round(sio.SESSION_IO_W,2) SESSION_IO_W_MBps,round(fio.TOTAL_IO, 2) TOTAL_IO_MBps,p.DESCRIPTION, sio.sql_full_plan_hash_value from gv$session b, gv$bgprocess p, ( select inst_id, sum(((DELTA_READ_IO_BYTES/1024/1024)+(DELTA_WRITE_IO_BYTES/1024/1024))/(DELTA_TIME/1000000))/600 total_io from GV$ACTIVE_SESSION_HISTORY where sample_time > sysdate-10/24/60 group by inst_id ) fio,( select inst_id, session_id,sum((DELTA_READ_IO_BYTES/1024/1024)/(DELTA_TIME/1000000))/600 session_io_r, sum((DELTA_WRITE_IO_BYTES/1024/1024)/(DELTA_TIME/1000000))/600 session_io_w, sql_full_plan_hash_value from GV$ACTIVE_SESSION_HISTORY where sample_time > sysdate-10/24/60 group by inst_id, session_id, sql_full_plan_hash_value ) sio where p.paddr(+) = b.paddr and p.inst_id(+)=b.inst_id and sio.session_id = b.sid and sio.inst_id=b.inst_id and fio.inst_id=b.inst_id order by PCT desc nulls last ) where rownum < 11) </query>
<query time="600" item="archivelog_size[%1]" nodata="0"> select A.inst_id, round(A.LOGS*B.AVG/10) from ( SELECT inst_id, COUNT (*) LOGS FROM GV$LOG_HISTORY WHERE FIRST_TIME >= (sysdate -10/60/24) group by inst_id ) A, ( SELECT inst_id, Avg(BYTES) AVG, Count(1), Max(BYTES) Max_Bytes, Min(BYTES) Min_Bytes FROM gv$log group by inst_id ) B where A.inst_id=B.inst_id </query>
<query time="120" item="db_locks" nodata="none"> select SUBSTR( sessions,1,2040)session_cut from ( select LISTAGG(SUBSTR(sessions_tab,1,395), chr(10)) WITHIN GROUP (ORDER BY sessions_tab desc) sessions from ( select blocking_sessions.inst_id||':'||chr(9)|| 'OBJ: '||o.owner || '.' ||o.object_name ||chr(10)||chr(9)||chr(9)|| 'BG: SID=' || blocking_sessions.sid ||'/'||blocking_sessions.serial#||'|'||blocking_sessions.status || '|USER/SCHEMA=' ||blocking_sessions.username||'/'||blocking_sessions.schemaname || '|OSUSER=' ||blocking_sessions.osuser || '|' ||REGEXP_REPLACE(blocking_sessions.program,'@.*$','') || '@' ||blocking_sessions.machine || '|' ||blocking_sessions.sql_id ||chr(10)||chr(9)||chr(9)|| 'BD: SID=' || blocked_sessions.sid ||'/' || blocked_sessions.serial#||'|'||blocked_sessions.status || '|USER/SCHEMA=' ||blocked_sessions.username||'/'||blocked_sessions.schemaname || '|OSUSER=' ||blocked_sessions.osuser || '|' ||REGEXP_REPLACE(blocked_sessions.program,'@.*','')||'@'||blocked_sessions.machine || '|' ||blocked_sessions.sql_id sessions_tab from ( select inst_id,sid,serial#,status,username,schemaname,osuser,machine,program,blocking_session,final_blocking_session, row_wait_obj# blocked_objects,sql_id from gv$session where event like 'enq:%' and final_blocking_session_status = 'VALID' ) blocked_sessions, gv$session blocking_sessions, dba_objects o where blocking_sessions.inst_id=blocked_sessions.inst_id and blocking_sessions.sid = blocked_sessions.final_blocking_session and o.object_id = blocked_sessions.blocked_objects ) where rownum < 11 ) </query>
<query time="120" item="db_pga[%1]" nodata="0"> select inst_id, value from GV$PGASTAT where name in 'total PGA inuse' </query>
<multiquery time="120" items="dbwaits_latch[%1]|dbwaits_logwrite[%1]|dbwaits_file_io[%1]|waits_directpath_read[%1]|dbwaits_multiblock_read[%1]|dbwaits_other[%1]|dbwaits_singleblock_read[%1]|dbwaits_sqlnet[%1]" nodata="0" type="column"> SELECT inst_id, to_char(sum(decode(event,'control file sequential read', total_waits,'control file single write', total_waits, 'control file parallel write',total_waits,0))) ControlFileIO, to_char(sum(decode(event,'log file single write',total_waits, 'log file parallel write',total_waits,0))) LogWrite, to_char(sum(decode(event,'file identify',total_waits, 'file open',total_waits,0))) FileIO, to_char(sum(decode(event,'direct path read',total_waits,0))) DirectPathRead, to_char(sum(decode(event,'db file scattered read',total_waits,0))) MultiBlockRead, to_char(sum(decode(event,'control file sequential read',0,'control file single write',0,'control file parallel write',0,'db file sequential read',0,'db file scattered read',0,'direct path read',0,'file identify',0,'file open',0,'SQL*Net message to client',0,'SQL*Net message to dblink',0, 'SQL*Net more data to client',0,'SQL*Net more data to dblink',0, 'SQL*Net break/reset to client',0,'SQL*Net break/reset to dblink',0, 'log file single write',0,'log file parallel write',0,total_waits))) Other, to_char(sum(decode(event,'db file sequential read',total_waits,0))) SingleBlockRead, to_char(sum(decode(event,'SQL*Net message to client',total_waits,'SQL*Net message to dblink',total_waits,'SQL*Net more data to client',total_waits,'SQL*Net more data to dblink',total_waits,'SQL*Net break/reset to client',total_waits,'SQL*Net break/reset to dblink',total_waits,0))) SQLNET FROM GV$system_event WHERE event not in ('SQL*Net message from client','SQL*Net more data from client','pmon timer', 'rdbms ipc message','rdbms ipc reply', 'smon timer') group by inst_id </multiquery>
<query time="60" item="zabbix[%1,%2]" nodata="none"> select inst_id,'activesessions', count(*) activeSessions from gv$session where SCHEMANAME=upper('{$DB_USER}') and SQL_EXEC_START is not null group by inst_id </query>
<query time="60" item="zabbix[%1,%2]" nodata="none"> select inst_id, 'sessions', count(*) Sessions from gv$session where SCHEMANAME=upper('{$DB_USER}') group by inst_id </query>
<query time="600" item="zabbix_session_io_log" nodata="none"> select LISTAGG(SUBSTR(sessions_tab,1,395),chr(10)) WITHIN GROUP(ORDER BY PCT desc) sessions from ( select INST_ID||': '||'PCT[R/W/T,MB/s]='||PCT||'['||SESSION_IO_R_MBps||'/'||SESSION_IO_W_MBps||'/'||TOTAL_IO_MBps||'];SQL_(ID/FULL_PLAN_HV)='||SQL_ID||'/'||sql_full_plan_hash_value||';SID='||sid||'#'||SERIAL#||';(SCH/USER)NAME='||SCHEMANAME||'/'||USERNAME||';STATUS='||STATUS||';TYPE='||TYPE||';OSUSER='||OSUSER||';PROGRAM='||REGEXP_REPLACE(PROGRAM,'@.*$','')||'@'||MACHINE||';PROCESS='||PROCESS||';'||DESCRIPTION sessions_tab, PCT from ( select b.inst_id,b.sid,b.SERIAL#,b.SCHEMANAME,b.OSUSER,b.USERNAME,b.STATUS,b.SQL_ID,b.PROCESS,b.PROGRAM,b.MACHINE,b.TYPE, round(100*(sio.SESSION_IO_R+sio.SESSION_IO_W)/fio.TOTAL_IO,2) PCT,round(sio.SESSION_IO_R,2) SESSION_IO_R_MBps, round(sio.SESSION_IO_W,2) SESSION_IO_W_MBps,round(fio.TOTAL_IO, 2) TOTAL_IO_MBps,p.DESCRIPTION, sio.sql_full_plan_hash_value from gv$session b, gv$bgprocess p, ( select inst_id, sum(((DELTA_READ_IO_BYTES/1024/1024)+(DELTA_WRITE_IO_BYTES/1024/1024))/(DELTA_TIME/1000000))/600 total_io from GV$ACTIVE_SESSION_HISTORY where sample_time > sysdate-10/24/60 group by inst_id ) fio,( select inst_id, session_id,sum((DELTA_READ_IO_BYTES/1024/1024)/(DELTA_TIME/1000000))/600 session_io_r, sum((DELTA_WRITE_IO_BYTES/1024/1024)/(DELTA_TIME/1000000))/600 session_io_w, sql_full_plan_hash_value from GV$ACTIVE_SESSION_HISTORY where sample_time > sysdate-10/24/60 group by inst_id, session_id, sql_full_plan_hash_value ) sio where p.paddr(+) = b.paddr and p.inst_id(+)=b.inst_id and sio.session_id = b.sid and sio.inst_id=b.inst_id and fio.inst_id=b.inst_id and b.SCHEMANAME = upper('{$DB_USER}') order by PCT desc nulls last ) where rownum < 11) </query>
<multiquery time="60" items="zabbixsessionioread[%1]|zabbixsessioniowrite[%1]" nodata="none" type="column"> select ash.inst_id, sum((DELTA_READ_IO_BYTES/(DELTA_TIME/1000000))/60), sum((DELTA_WRITE_IO_BYTES/(DELTA_TIME/1000000))/60) from GV$ACTIVE_SESSION_HISTORY ash JOIN dba_users u on username=upper('{$DB_USER}') where sample_time > sysdate - 1/24/60 and u.user_id=ash.USER_ID group by ash.inst_id </multiquery>
</server> </parms>

discovery_rule.name: Librarycache
discovery_rule.params: <parms type="oracle" prefix="oracle."> <server> <discovery time="120" item="discovery.DBforBIX.config[librarycache,{$DSN}]" names="NAMESPACE">SELECT REPLACE(namespace,' ','_') FROM v$librarycache</discovery> <query time="120" item="librarycache.hitratio[%1]">SELECT REPLACE(namespace,' ','_'), trunc(gethitratio*100,2) get_pct FROM v$librarycache</query> <query time="120" item="librarycache.pinhitratio[%1]">SELECT REPLACE(namespace,' ','_'), trunc(pins/(pins+reloads)*100,2) pin_hit_ratio FROM v$librarycache WHERE (pins+reloads)!=0</query> </server> </parms>

discovery_rule.name: Tablespaces
discovery_rule.params: <parms type="oracle" prefix="oracle."> <server> <discovery time="600" item="discovery.DBforBIX.config[tablespace,{$DSN}]" names="TABLESPACE">SELECT DISTINCT name FROM v$tablespace WHERE name NOT IN ('TEMP')</discovery> <multiquery time="300" items="tablespace.bytes[%1]|tablespace.freebytes[%1]" type="column">SELECT a.tablespace_name,total AS bytes, free AS maxbytes FROM (SELECT tablespace_name, SUM(bytes) free FROM dba_free_space GROUP BY tablespace_name) a, (SELECT tablespace_name, SUM(bytes) total FROM dba_data_files GROUP BY tablespace_name) b WHERE a.tablespace_name = b.tablespace_name</multiquery> </server> </parms>

discovery_rule.name: Discovery ASM diskgroup
discovery_rule.params:
<parms type="oracle" prefix="oracle."> <server> <discovery time="300" item="discovery.DBforBIX.config[ASM,{$DSN}]" names="INST_ID|NAME"> select INST_ID, NAME from gv$asm_diskgroup </discovery> <multiquery time="120" items="asm[FREE_MB,%1,%2]|asm[TOTAL_MB,%1,%2]" type="column"> select INST_ID, NAME, FREE_MB,TOTAL_MB from gv$asm_diskgroup </multiquery>
<multiquery time="60" items="asm[reads,%1,%2]|asm[writes,%1,%2]|asm[read_util,%1,%2]|asm[write_util,%1,%2]|asm[read_bytes,%1,%2]|asm[write_bytes,%1,%2]" type="column"> select dg.inst_id, dg.name, sum(reads), sum(writes), avg(read_time), avg(write_time), sum(bytes_read), sum(bytes_written) from gv$asm_disk_stat ds, gv$asm_diskgroup dg where ds.group_number=dg.group_number and ds.inst_id=dg.inst_id group by dg.inst_id, dg.name </multiquery>
</server> </parms>

template.template: Template Module Cisco CISCO-PROCESS-MIB IOS later to 12.0_3_T and prior to 12.2_3.5 SNMPv2
template.name: Template Module Cisco CISCO-PROCESS-MIB IOS later to 12.0_3_T and prior to 12.2_3.5 SNMPv2
template.description: Template Cisco CISCO-PROCESS-MIB IOS later to 12.0_3_T and prior to 12.2_3.5 version: 0.11 MIBs used: CISCO-PROCESS-MIB

discovery_rule.name: CPU Discovery
discovery_rule.description: If your IOS device has several CPUs, you must use CISCO-PROCESS-MIB and its object cpmCPUTotal5minRev from the table called cpmCPUTotalTable , indexed with cpmCPUTotalIndex . This table allows CISCO-PROCESS-MIB to keep CPU statistics for different physical entities in the router, like different CPU chips, group of CPUs, or CPUs in different modules/cards. In case of a single CPU, cpmCPUTotalTable has only one entry.

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: CPU utilization
item_prototype.description: MIB: CISCO-PROCESS-MIB The overall CPU busy percentage in the last 5 minute period. This object deprecates the avgBusy5 object from the OLD-CISCO-SYSTEM-MIB. This object is deprecated by cpmCPUTotal5minRev which has the changed range of value (0..100) Reference: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/simple-network-management-protocol-snmp/15215-collect-cpu-util-snmp.html

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Cisco CISCO-PROCESS-MIB IOS later to 12.0_3_T and prior to 12.2_3.5 SNMPv2:system.cpu.util[cpmCPUTotal5min.{#SNMPINDEX}].avg(5m)}>{$CPU_UTIL_MAX}
trigger_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: High CPU utilization
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}.

item.host: Template Module Cisco CISCO-PROCESS-MIB IOS later to 12.0_3_T and prior to 12.2_3.5 SNMPv2

template.name: Template Module Cisco CISCO-PROCESS-MIB SNMPv2
template.description: Template Cisco CISCO-PROCESS-MIB version: 0.11 MIBs used: CISCO-PROCESS-MIB

discovery_rule.name: CPU Discovery
discovery_rule.description: If your IOS device has several CPUs, you must use CISCO-PROCESS-MIB and its object cpmCPUTotal5minRev from the table called cpmCPUTotalTable , indexed with cpmCPUTotalIndex . This table allows CISCO-PROCESS-MIB to keep CPU statistics for different physical entities in the router, like different CPU chips, group of CPUs, or CPUs in different modules/cards. In case of a single CPU, cpmCPUTotalTable has only one entry.

item_prototype.name: #{#SNMPINDEX}: CPU utilization
item_prototype.description: MIB: CISCO-PROCESS-MIB The cpmCPUTotal5minRev MIB object provides a more accurate view of the performance of the router over time than the MIB objects cpmCPUTotal1minRev and cpmCPUTotal5secRev . These MIB objects are not accurate because they look at CPU at one minute and five second intervals, respectively. These MIBs enable you to monitor the trends and plan the capacity of your network. The recommended baseline rising threshold for cpmCPUTotal5minRev is 90 percent. Depending on the platform, some routers that run at 90 percent, for example, 2500s, can exhibit performance degradation versus a high-end router, for example, the 7500 series, which can operate fine. Reference: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/ip/simple-network-management-protocol-snmp/15215-collect-cpu-util-snmp.html

trigger_prototype.name: #{#SNMPINDEX}: High CPU utilization
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}.

template.name: Template Module EtherLike-MIB SNMPv1
template.description: Template EtherLike-MIB (duplex control only) version: 0.11 MIBs used: EtherLike-MIB

discovery_rule.name: EtherLike-MIB Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovering interfaces from IF-MIB and EtherLike-MIB. Interfaces with up(1) Operational Status are discovered.

item_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Duplex status
item_prototype.description:
MIB: EtherLike-MIB The current mode of operation of the MAC entity. 'unknown' indicates that the current duplex mode could not be determined.
Management control of the duplex mode is accomplished through the MAU MIB. When an interface does not support autonegotiation, or when autonegotiation is not enabled, the duplex mode is controlled using ifMauDefaultType. When autonegotiation is supported and enabled, duplex mode is controlled using ifMauAutoNegAdvertisedBits. In either case, the currently operating duplex mode is reflected both in this object and in ifMauType.
Note that this object provides redundant information with ifMauType. Normally, redundant objects are discouraged. However, in this instance, it allows a management application to determine the duplex status of an interface without having to know every possible value of ifMauType. This was felt to be sufficiently valuable to justify the redundancy. Reference: [IEEE 802.3 Std.], 30.3.1.1.32,aDuplexStatus.

trigger_prototype.name: {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): In half-duplex mode
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check autonegotiation settings and cabling

template.name: Template Module Generic SNMPv1
template.description: Template Module Generic version: 0.11 MIBs used: SNMPv2-MIB

item.name: SNMP traps (fallback)
item.description: Item is used to collect all SNMP traps unmatched by other snmptrap items

item.name: Device contact details
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The textual identification of the contact person for this managed node, together with information on how to contact this person. If no contact information is known, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: Device description
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB A textual description of the entity. This value should include the full name and version identification of the system's hardware type, software operating-system, and networking software.

item.name: Device location
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The physical location of this node (e.g., `telephone closet, 3rd floor'). If the location is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: Device name
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB An administratively-assigned name for this managed node.By convention, this is the node's fully-qualified domain name. If the name is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

item.name: System object ID
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The vendor's authoritative identification of the network management subsystem contained in the entity. This value is allocated within the SMI enterprises subtree (1.3.6.1.4.1) and provides an easy and unambiguous means for determining`what kind of box' is being managed. For example, if vendor`Flintstones, Inc.' was assigned the subtree1.3.6.1.4.1.4242, it could assign the identifier 1.3.6.1.4.1.4242.1.1 to its `Fred Router'.

item.name: Device uptime
item.description: MIB: SNMPv2-MIB The time (in hundredths of a second) since the network management portion of the system was last re-initialized.

This object is writable to allow remote configuration of the size of the storage area in those cases where such an operation makes sense and is possible on the underlying system. template.description: Template Module ICMP Ping version: 0.12

template.name: Template Module Interfaces Simple SNMPv1
template.description: Template Interfaces Simple (no ifXTable) version: 0.11 MIBs used: IF-MIB

discovery_rule.name: Network Interfaces Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovering interfaces from IF-MIB. Interfaces with down(2) Administrative Status are not discovered.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Inbound packets discarded
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The number of inbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Inbound packets with errors
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of inbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Bits received
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The total number of octets received on the interface,including framing characters. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occurat re-initialization of the management system, and atother times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Outbound packets discarded
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The number of outbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Outbound packets with errors
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of outbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Bits sent
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The total number of octets transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occurat re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Speed
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB An estimate of the interface's current bandwidth in bits per second. For interfaces which do not vary in bandwidth or for those where no accurate estimation can be made, this object should contain the nominal bandwidth. If the bandwidth of the interface is greater than the maximum value reportable by this object then this object should report its maximum value (4,294,967,295) and ifHighSpeed must be used to report the interace's speed. For a sub-layer which has no concept of bandwidth, this object should be zero.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFDESCR}: Operational status
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The current operational state of the interface. - The testing(3) state indicates that no operational packet scan be passed - If ifAdminStatus is down(2) then ifOperStatus should be down(2) - If ifAdminStatus is changed to up(1) then ifOperStatus should change to up(1) if the interface is ready to transmit and receive network traffic - It should change todormant(5) if the interface is waiting for external actions (such as a serial line waiting for an incoming connection) - It should remain in the down(2) state if and only if there is a fault that prevents it from going to the up(1) state - It should remain in the notPresent(6) state if the interface has missing(typically, hardware) components.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits sent
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The total number of octets transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters. This object is a 64-bit version of ifOutOctets.Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Speed
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB An estimate of the interface's current bandwidth in units of 1,000,000 bits per second. If this object reports a value of `n' then the speed of the interface is somewhere in the range of `n-500,000' to`n+499,999'. For interfaces which do not vary in bandwidth or for those where no accurate estimation can be made, this object should contain the nominal bandwidth. For a sub-layer which has no concept of bandwidth, this object should be zero.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Operational status
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The current operational state of the interface. - The testing(3) state indicates that no operational packet scan be passed - If ifAdminStatus is down(2) then ifOperStatus should be down(2) - If ifAdminStatus is changed to up(1) then ifOperStatus should change to up(1) if the interface is ready to transmit and receive network traffic - It should change todormant(5) if the interface is waiting for external actions (such as a serial line waiting for an incoming connection) - It should remain in the down(2) state if and only if there is a fault that prevents it from going to the up(1) state - It should remain in the notPresent(6) state if the interface has missing(typically, hardware) components.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Interface type
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The type of interface. Additional values for ifType are assigned by the Internet Assigned NumbersAuthority (IANA), through updating the syntax of the IANAifType textual convention.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}].change()}<0 and {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}>0 and ( {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=6 or {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=7 or {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=11 or {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=62 or {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=69 or {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=117 ) and ({Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}<>2)
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: ({Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}].change()}>0 and {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}].prev()}>0) or ({Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=2)
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Ethernet has changed to lower speed than it was before
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. This Ethernet connection has transitioned down from its known maximum speed. This might be a sign of autonegotiation issues. Ack to close.

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and ({Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=2 and {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].diff()}=1)

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.in[ifHCInOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}].avg(15m)}>({$IF_UTIL_MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*{Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()} or {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.out[ifHCOutOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}].avg(15m)}>({$IF_UTIL_MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*{Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.in[ifHCInOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}].avg(15m)}<(({$IF_UTIL_MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*{Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()} or {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.out[ifHCOutOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}].avg(15m)}<(({$IF_UTIL_MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*{Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High bandwidth usage >{$IF_UTIL_MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}%
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}.

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and ({Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=2 and {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].diff()}=1)

trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High error rate
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}.

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and ({Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=2 and {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].diff()}=1)

trigger_prototype.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and ({Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].last()}=2 and {Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2:net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].diff()}=1)
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Interface is down

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Inbound packets discarded
item_prototype.description: MIB: IF-MIB The number of inbound packets which were chosen to be discarded even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits received

item.name: Overall system health status
item.description: MIB: SW-MIB The current operational status of the switch.The states are as follow: online(1) means the switch is accessible by an external Fibre Channel port offline(2) means the switch is not accessible testing(3) means the switch is in a built-in test mode and is not accessible by an external Fibre Channel port faulty(4) means the switch is not operational.

item_prototype.description:
MIB: SW-MIB
The current value (reading) of the sensor. The value, -2147483648, represents an unknown quantity. The fan value will be in RPM(revolution per minute)

template.name: Template Net Brocade_Foundry Nonstackable SNMPv2
template.description:
Template Net Brocade_Foundry Nonstackable version: 0.11 Overview: For devices(old Foundry devices, MLXe and so on) that doesn't support Stackable SNMP Tables: snChasFan2Table, snChasPwrSupply2Table,snAgentTemp2Table - FOUNDRY-SN-AGENT-MIB::snChasFanTable, snChasPwrSupplyTable,snAgentTempTable are used instead. For example: The objects in table snChasPwrSupply2Table is not supported on the NetIron and the FastIron SX devices. snChasFan2Table is not supported on on the NetIron devices. snAgentTemp2Table is not supported on old versions of MLXe
MIBs used: FOUNDRY-SN-AGENT-MIB

Known Issues: description : No temperature sensors. All entities of them return 0 for HH3C-ENTITY-EXT-MIB::hh3cEntityExtTemperature version : 1910-48 Switch Software Version 5.20.99, Release 1116 Copyright(c)2010-2016 Hewlett Packard Enterprise Development LP device : HP 1910-48

discovery_rule.name: FAN Discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovering all entities of PhysicalClass - 7: fan(7)

item_prototype.name: {#ENT_NAME}: Fan status
item_prototype.description: MIB: HH3C-ENTITY-EXT-MIB Indicate the error state of this entity object. fanError(41) means that the fan stops working.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Net HP Comware HH3C SNMPv2:sensor.fan.status[hh3cEntityExtErrorStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].last(0)}={$FAN_CRIT_STATUS:"fanError"} or {Template Net HP Comware HH3C SNMPv2:sensor.fan.status[hh3cEntityExtErrorStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}].last(0)}={$FAN_CRIT_STATUS:"hardwareFaulty"}
trigger_prototype.name: {#ENT_NAME}: Fan is in critical state
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the fan unit

item_prototype.name: {#MODULE_NAME}: CPU utilization
item_prototype.description: MIB: HH3C-ENTITY-EXT-MIB The CPU usage for this entity. Generally, the CPU usage will calculate the overall CPU usage on the entity, and it is not sensible with the number of CPU on the entity

item_prototype.name: {#MODULE_NAME}: Memory utilization
item_prototype.description: MIB: HH3C-ENTITY-EXT-MIB The memory usage for the entity. This object indicates what percent of memory are used.

discovery_rule.description: A textual description of the power supply, that can be assigned by the administrator.

item_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Power supply status
item_prototype.description: MIB: ICS-CHASSIS-MIB Actual status of the power supply: (1) unknown: status not known. (2) disabled: power supply is disabled. (3) failed - power supply is unable to supply power due to failure. (4) warning - power supply is supplying power, but an output or sensor is bad or warning. (5) standby - power supply believed usable,but not supplying power. (6) engaged - power supply is supplying power. (7) redundant - power supply is supplying power, but not needed. (8) notPresent - power supply is supplying power is not present.

trigger_prototype.name: {#SNMPVALUE}: Power supply is in critical state
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Please check the power supply unit for errors

template.description: Template Net Juniper version: 0.11 MIBs used: JUNIPER-MIB JUNIPER-ALARM-MIB SNMPv2-MIB

item.name: Hardware model name
item.description: MIB: JUNIPER-MIB The name, model, or detailed description of the box,indicating which product the box is about, for example 'M40'.

item.name: Hardware serial number
item.description: MIB: JUNIPER-MIB The serial number of this subject, blank if unknown or unavailable.

item.name: Overall system health status
item.description:
MIB: JUNIPER-ALARM-MIB The red alarm indication on the craft interface panel. The red alarm is on when there is some system failure or power supply failure or the system is experiencing a hardware malfunction or some threshold is being exceeded.
This red alarm state could be turned off by the ACO/LT (Alarm Cut Off / Lamp Test) button on the front panel module.

template.name: Template OS Windows SNMPv2
template.description: Template OS Windows version: 0.11 Known Issues: description : Doesn't support In/Out 64 bit counters even thoug1h IfxTable is present: Currently, Windows gets it’s interface status from MIB-2. Since these 64bit SNMP counters (ifHCInOctets, ifHCOutOctets, etc.) are defined as an extension to IF-MIB, Microsoft has not implemented it. https://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/windowsserver/en-US/07b62ff0-94f6-40ca-a99d-d129c1b33d70/windows-2008-r2-snmp-64bit-counters-support?forum=winservergen version : Win2008, Win2012R2 device : description : Doesn't support ifXTable at all version : WindowsXP device : description : EtherLike MIB is not supported version : * device : *

item.name: Client connections (SSL)
item.description: The current number of concurrent connections with established SSL sessions being maintained by the filter.

item.name: Client SSL connections per second (compat)
item.description: The current number of concurrent compat connections with established SSL sessions being maintained by the filter.

item.name: Client SSL connections per second (native)
item.description: The total number of concurrent native connections with established SSL sessions being maintained by the filter.

item.name: Failover status
item.description: The failover status ID on the system. unknown - the failover status of the device is unknown. offline - the device is offline. forcedOffline - the device is forced offline. standby - the device is standby. active - the device is active.

item.name: Sync status
item.description: The sync status ID on the system. unknown - the device is disconnected from the device group syncing - the device is joining the device group or has requested changes from device group or inconsistent with the group. needManualSync - changes have been made on the device not syncd to the device group. inSync - the device is consistent with the device group. syncFailed - the device is inconsistent with the device group, requires user intervention. syncDisconnected - the device is not connected to any peers. standalone - the device is in a standalone configuration. awaitingInitialSync - the device is waiting for initial sync. incompatibleVersion - the device's version is incompatible with rest of the devices in the device group. partialSync - some but not all devices successfully received the last sync.

item.name: CPU idle time
item.description: The average time spent by the specified processor doing nothing for the system in the last five seconds.

item.name: CPU iowait time
item.description: The average time spent by the specified processor waiting for external I/O to complete for the system in the last five seconds.

item.name: CPU interrupt time
item.description: The average time spent by the specified processor servicing hardware interrupts for the system in the last five seconds.

item.name: CPU nice time
item.description: The average time spent by the specified processor running niced processes for the system in the last five seconds.

item.name: CPU softirq time
item.description: The average time spent by the specified processor servicing soft interrupts for the system in the last five seconds.

item.name: CPU steel time
item.description: The average time 'stolen' from the system in the last five seconds.

item.name: CPU system time
item.description: The average time spent by the specified processor servicing system calls for the system in the last five seconds.

item.name: CPU average usage ratio
item.description: This is average usage ratio of CPU for the system in the last one minute. It is calculated by (sum of deltas for user, niced, system)/(sum of deltas of user, niced, system, idle, irq, softirq, and iowait), where each delta is the difference for each stat over the last 1-minute interval.

item.name: CPU user time
item.description: The average time spent by the specified processor in user context for the system in the last five seconds.

item.name: Total memory
item.description: The total host memory in bytes. This is for a single host system. For multiple host system, please refer sysMultiHost table.

item.name: Used memory
item.description: The host memory in bytes currently in use. This is for a single host system. For multiple host system, please refer sysMultiHost table.

item.name: Product name (marketing)
item.description: The system name used by marketing

item.name: Product build
item.description: The product build number.

item.name: Product edition
item.description: The product edition.

item.name: Product name
item.description: The product name.

item.name: Product version
item.description: The product version.

item.name: Server connections (SSL)
item.description: The current number of concurrent connections with established SSL sessions being maintained by the filter.

item.name: Server SSL connections per second (compat)
item.description: The total number of concurrent compat connections with established SSL sessions being maintained by the filter.

item.name: Server SSL connections per second (native)
item.description: The total number of concurrent native connections with established SSL sessions being maintained by the filter.

item.name: Client Bytes In
item.description: The number of bytes received by the system from client-side.

item.name: Client Bytes Out
item.description: The number of bytes sent to client-side from the system.

item.name: Client connections
item.description: The current connections from client-side to the system.

item.name: Client Packets In
item.description: The average number of packets received by the system from client-side in the last five seconds.

item.name: Client Packets Out
item.description: The number of packets sent to client-side from the system.

item.name: Client connects per second
item.description: The total connections from client-side to the system.

item.name: HTTP Requests per second
item.description: The total number of HTTP requests to the system.

item.name: Total memory (TMM)
item.description: The total memory available in bytes for TMM (Traffic Management Module).

item.name: Used memory (TMM)
item.description: The memory in use in bytes for TMM (Traffic Management Module).

item.name: Server Bytes In
item.description: The number of bytes received by the system from server-side.

item.name: Server Bytes Out
item.description: The number of bytes sent to server-side from the system.

item.name: Server connections
item.description: The current connections from server-side to the system.

item.name: Server connects per second
item.description: The total connections from server-side to the system.

item.name: Host name
item.description: The host name of the system on the network.

item.name: Uptime
item.description: The system up time in 1/100 seconds since boot.

item.name: Client accepts per second
item.description: The number of connections accepted.

item.name: SNMP trap for F5-BIGIP-COMMON-MIB notifications
item.description: A private enterprise MIB for F5 Networks Top-level infrastructure of the F5 enterprise MIB tree.

discovery_rule.name: Node stats discovery
discovery_rule.description: node name.

item_prototype.name: Node {#SNMPVALUE} current sessions
item_prototype.description: The number of current sessions going through the specified node address.

item_prototype.name: Node {#SNMPVALUE} incoming bytes
item_prototype.description: The number of bytes received by the specified node address from server-side.

item_prototype.name: Node {#SNMPVALUE} outgoing bytes
item_prototype.description: The number of bytes sent to server-side from the specified node address.

item_prototype.name: Node {#SNMPVALUE} current server connections
item_prototype.description: The current connections from server-side to the specified node address.

item_prototype.name: Node {#SNMPVALUE} incoming packets
item_prototype.description: The number of packets received by the specified node address from server-side.

item_prototype.name: Node {#SNMPVALUE} outgoing packets
item_prototype.description: The number of packets sent to server-side from the specified node address.

discovery_rule.name: Node status discovery
discovery_rule.description: node name.

item_prototype.name: Node {#SNMPVALUE} available
item_prototype.description: The availability of the specified node address indicated in color. none - error. green - available in some capacity. yellow - not currently available. red - not available. blue - availability is unknown. gray - unlicensed.

item_prototype.name: Node {#SNMPVALUE} state
item_prototype.description: The activity status of the specified node address, as specified by the user.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template SNMP f5 BIG-IP ADC:ltmNodeAddrStatusEnabledState[{#SNMPVALUE}].last()}=1 and {Template SNMP f5 BIG-IP ADC:ltmNodeAddrStatusAvailState[{#SNMPVALUE}].last()}<>1 and {Template SNMP f5 BIG-IP ADC:ltmNodeAddrStatusAvailState[{#SNMPVALUE}].last()}<>4
trigger_prototype.name: Node {#SNMPVALUE} is not available in some capacity: {ITEM.VALUE2}

discovery_rule.name: Pool status discovery
discovery_rule.description: The name of a pool.

item_prototype.name: Pool {#SNMPVALUE} available
Pool {#SNMPVALUE} enabled
item_prototype.description: The activity status of the specified pool, as specified by the user.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template SNMP f5 BIG-IP ADC:ltmPoolStatusEnabledState[{#SNMPVALUE}].last()}=1 and {Template SNMP f5 BIG-IP ADC:ltmPoolStatusAvailState[{#SNMPVALUE}].last()}<>1 and {Template SNMP f5 BIG-IP ADC:ltmPoolStatusAvailState[{#SNMPVALUE}].last()}<>4
trigger_prototype.name: Pool {#SNMPVALUE} is not available in some capacity: {ITEM.VALUE2}

discovery_rule.name: Virtual server status discovery
discovery_rule.description: The name of a virtual server.

item_prototype.name: Virtual server {#SNMPVALUE} availability
Virtual server {#SNMPVALUE} enabled
item_prototype.description: The activity status of the specified virtual server, as specified by the user.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template SNMP f5 BIG-IP ADC:ltmVsStatusEnabledState[{#SNMPVALUE}].last()}=1 and {Template SNMP f5 BIG-IP ADC:ltmVsStatusAvailState[{#SNMPVALUE}].last()}<>1 and {Template SNMP f5 BIG-IP ADC:ltmVsStatusAvailState[{#SNMPVALUE}].last()}<>4
trigger_prototype.name: Virtual server {#SNMPVALUE} is not available in some capacity: {ITEM.VALUE2}

discovery_rule.name: Chassis fan discovery
discovery_rule.description: The index of a chassis fan on the system. It identifies a particular chassis fan.

item_prototype.name: Chassis fan {#SNMPVALUE} speed
item_prototype.description: The actual speed of the indexed chassis fan on the system. This is only supported for the platform where the actual fan speed data is available. '0' means fan speed is unavailable while the associated chassis status is good.

item_prototype.name: Chassis fan {#SNMPVALUE} status
item_prototype.description: The status of the indexed chassis fan on the system. This is only supported for the platform where the sensor data is available.

trigger_prototype.name: Chassis fan {#SNMPVALUE} is in bad state

discovery_rule.name: Power supply discovery
discovery_rule.description: The index of a power supply on the system.

item_prototype.name: Power supply {#SNMPVALUE} status
item_prototype.description: The status of the indexed power supply on the system. This is only supported for the platform where the sensor data is available.

trigger_prototype.name: Power supply {#SNMPVALUE} is in bad state

discovery_rule.name: Chassis temperature discovery
discovery_rule.description: The index of a chassis temperature sensor on the system. It identifies a particular chassis temperature sensor, fan, etc.

item_prototype.name: Chassis sensor {#SNMPVALUE} temperature
item_prototype.description: The chassis temperature (in Celsius) of the indexed sensor on the system. This is only supported for the platform where the sensor data is available.

trigger_prototype.name: Chassis temperature ({ITEM.LASTVALUE}) of sensor {#SNMPVALUE} exceeds threshold of {$TEMP_HIGH} °C
Chassis temperature ({ITEM.LASTVALUE}) of sensor {#SNMPVALUE} exceeds threshold of {$TEMP_WARN} °C

discovery_rule.description: Discovery of clusters

discovery_rule.name: Discover VMware hypervisors
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of hypervisors.

discovery_rule.name: Discover VMware VMs
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of guest virtual machines.

item.name: Cluster name
item.description: Cluster name of the guest VM.

item.name: Number of virtual CPUs
item.description: Number of virtual CPUs assigned to the guest.

item.name: CPU ready
item.description: Time that the virtual machine was ready, but could not get scheduled to run on the physical CPU during last measurement interval (VMware vCenter/ESXi Server performance counter sampling interval - 20 seconds)

item.name: CPU usage
item.description: Current upper-bound on CPU usage. The upper-bound is based on the host the virtual machine is current running on, as well as limits configured on the virtual machine itself or any parent resource pool. Valid while the virtual machine is running.

item.name: Datacenter name
item.description: Datacenter name of the guest VM.

item.name: Hypervisor name
item.description: Hypervisor name of the guest VM.

item.name: Ballooned memory
item.description: The amount of guest physical memory that is currently reclaimed through the balloon driver.

item.name: Compressed memory
item.description: The amount of memory currently in the compression cache for this VM.

item.name: Private memory
item.description: Amount of memory backed by host memory and not being shared.

item.name: Shared memory
item.description: The amount of guest physical memory shared through transparent page sharing.

item.name: Swapped memory
item.description: The amount of guest physical memory swapped out to the VM's swap device by ESX.

item.name: Guest memory usage
item.description: The amount of guest physical memory that is being used by the VM.

item.name: Host memory usage
item.description: The amount of host physical memory allocated to the VM, accounting for saving from memory sharing with other VMs.

item.name: Memory size
item.description: Total size of configured memory.

item.name: Power state
item.description: The current power state of the virtual machine.

item.name: Committed storage space
item.description: Total storage space, in bytes, committed to this virtual machine across all datastores.

item.name: Uncommitted storage space
item.description: Additional storage space, in bytes, potentially used by this virtual machine on all datastores.

item.name: Unshared storage space
item.description: Total storage space, in bytes, occupied by the virtual machine across all datastores, that is not shared with any other virtual machine.

item.name: Uptime
item.description: System uptime.

discovery_rule.name: Network device discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of all network devices.

item_prototype.name: Number of bytes received on interface {#IFDESC}
Number of packets received on interface {#IFDESC}
Number of bytes transmitted on interface {#IFDESC}
Number of packets transmitted on interface {#IFDESC}

discovery_rule.name: Disk device discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of all disk devices.

item_prototype.name: Average number of bytes read from the disk {#DISKDESC}
Average number of reads from the disk {#DISKDESC}
Average number of bytes written to the disk {#DISKDESC}
Average number of writes to the disk {#DISKDESC}

discovery_rule.name: Mounted filesystem discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of all guest file systems.

trigger_prototype.name: Free disk space is less than 20% on volume {#FSNAME}

item.name: Cluster name
item.description: Cluster name of the guest VM.

item.name: CPU usage
item.description: Aggregated CPU usage across all cores on the host in Hz. This is only available if the host is connected.

item.name: Datacenter name
item.description: Datacenter name of the hypervisor.

item.name: Full name
item.description: The complete product name, including the version information.

item.name: CPU frequency
item.description: The speed of the CPU cores. This is an average value if there are multiple speeds. The product of CPU frequency and number of cores is approximately equal to the sum of the MHz for all the individual cores on the host.

item.name: CPU model
item.description: The CPU model.

item.name: CPU cores
item.description: Number of physical CPU cores on the host. Physical CPU cores are the processors contained by a CPU package.

item.name: CPU threads
item.description: Number of physical CPU threads on the host.

item.name: Total memory
item.description: The physical memory size.

item.name: Model
item.description: The system model identification.

item.name: Bios UUID
item.description: The hardware BIOS identification.

item.name: Vendor
item.description: The hardware vendor identification.

item.name: Ballooned memory
item.description: The amount of guest physical memory that is currently reclaimed through the balloon driver. Sum of all guest VMs.

item.name: Used memory
item.description: Physical memory usage on the host.

item.name: Health state rollup
item.description: The host health state rollup sensor value: gray - unknown, ok, red - it has a problem, yellow - it might have a problem.

item.name: Overall status
item.description: The overall alarm status of the host: gray - unknown, ok, red - it has a problem, yellow - it might have a problem.

item.name: Uptime
item.description: System uptime.

item.name: Version
item.description: Dot-separated version string.

item.name: Number of guest VMs
item.description: Number of guest virtual machines.

item_prototype.name: Average read latency of the datastore $3
Average write latency of the datastore $3
